variations.narrative: A gap in the wall, above the waterline. Dry. Almost warm. Someone left supplies here. Maybe they made it out. Maybe they just left everything behind.
A natural pocket in the stone. Small enough to miss, large enough to hide. Inside: bandages, dried food, a note that says 'Take it. I won't need it.'
Behind a loose stone. You almost didn't check. Someone wanted this hidden. Someone who knew they wouldn't be coming back for it.
A crawlspace. Tight, but it opens into a small chamber. Supplies are stacked neatly. No dust — someone was here recently. Someone who left in a hurry.
An alcove marked with a survivor's symbol. The universal sign for 'safe enough.' Inside: what you need. Outside: everything else.
An altar to something nameless. Offerings rot at its base — but among them, something useful. Taking it feels like accepting a contract.
A shrine to water itself. Coins glitter beneath the surface of a pool. Other things too — weapons, herbs, hope. The water gives if you're willing to reach.
The faithful left gifts here. The faithful are gone. The gifts remain. Taking them might anger something. Not taking them seems like waste.
A statue of something that might have been worshipped. At its feet: supplies left by pilgrims. At its face: a knowing smile. It wants you to take them.
Candles surround a small bounty. The candles are fresh. Who lights them? Who leaves supplies for strangers? Don't think about it. Just take what you need.
Marks on the wall. Counting days? There are hundreds. Whoever was here survived longer than seems possible. They left everything behind. Did they escape, or simply give up?
A bedroll. A cold fire. A journal, the last page torn out. They lived here. For how long? Long enough to accumulate supplies. Long enough to suddenly leave.
Someone built a life down here. Furniture made from debris. Art scratched into walls. Then they abandoned it. Everything useful is neatly packed, waiting.
A survivor's camp. No body — they didn't die here. Their supplies are labeled, organized, left with intention. A gift for whoever comes next.
Weapons. Food. Medicine. Stacked against the far wall. A note reads: 'Couldn't carry it all. Didn't need to. Made it out.' Hope in ink.
Water trickles from the stone. Clear, not black. Something green grows at its edges — the only living thing you've seen. Drinking feels like hope. The aftertaste lingers.
A pool of clean water. A miracle down here. You can see the bottom. Nothing moves. Nothing lurks. It's safe. It has to be safe. Drink.
Steam rises from a crack in the floor. Warm water, mineral-rich, almost pleasant. The heat is alien after so much cold. Rest here. Recover.
An underground spring, fresh and cold. Others have camped here — you can see the marks. A safe place. As safe as anything gets.
The water here glows faintly. A soft blue. It's not dangerous — somehow you know this. Drinking it soothes wounds. Don't ask how. Don't ask why.
A bedroll. Cold ashes. Food half-eaten. They left fast. The supplies remain, but so does the question: what made someone abandon their only safe place?
Tents — plural. A group camped here. Their gear is scattered, panicked. Some took essentials. Some took nothing. What arrived wasn't worth packing for.
Everything is overturned. Signs of struggle? Signs of flight? The supplies are buried under chaos, but they're here. Whatever happened, it happened fast.
A watch post. Someone was on guard here. Their chair faces the wrong direction now. Their supplies are untouched. They saw something. They didn't finish seeing it.
Mid-meal. The food is still on plates. Still... edible, probably. They didn't even stop eating before they ran. Or were taken. The supplies don't answer questions.
Racks of weapons, pitted with age. An army was equipped here once. For what war? Against what enemy? Some blades still hold an edge. Help yourself.
A weapon cache, hidden in the walls. Someone prepared for a war that never came. Or a war that never ended. Their preparation is your survival.
Tools of violence, organized by type. The dust is thick. No one has been here in ages. No one except the things that don't need weapons.
A guard room. Empty now. The guards' equipment remains — corroded, but functional. They won't mind you borrowing it. They don't mind anything anymore.
Weapons embedded in the wall. Trophies? Storage? Art? The arrangement is deliberate. Take what calls to you. Something here was waiting for you specifically.
A figure in the dark. They have supplies. They have prices. Both are non-negotiable. In the underworld, commerce continues. The dead still deal.
The Collector sits among relics. 'Nothing is free. Everything costs. What are you willing to pay?' They spread their wares. The prices aren't in SOL.
'You have things. I have things. We can trade, or we can wait to see who takes whose things by force.' The merchant smiles. It's not a nice smile.
They call themselves a 'facilitator.' They facilitate the movement of items from dead hands to living ones. 'Everyone wins,' they say. 'Eventually, everyone's a supplier.'
A shop. Down here. Stocked with items from every dead adventurer who passed through. 'Recycling,' the keeper calls it. 'Sustainable.' The prices are your future possessions.
Skulls mounted on the walls. Claws displayed. Someone hunted here, successfully. Their trophies tell you what's ahead. Their supplies might help you survive it.
A hunter's den. Pelts, bones, things you don't recognize. Whoever lived here knew how to survive. Knew how to kill. Their tools are available. Their wisdom, less so.
Every creature from the depths, preserved and mounted. A catalogue of nightmares. Among them: supplies for creating more trophies. Or avoiding becoming one.
The first thing you see is the Drowned's head on a spike. Then the Crawler, pinned like a specimen. Someone was studying them. Their notes and supplies remain.
A monument to violence. Trophies of a hundred hunts. The hunter isn't here. The trophies suggest they rarely stay in one place. They rarely need to. Take what's useful.
They've been here years. Decades? Alone. Surviving. They don't want company, but they'll share what they know. And what they no longer need.
'You're the first visitor in... I've lost count.' The hermit's eyes are strange but not hostile. 'Take these. I've made more. I always make more.'
A philosopher of the depths. They've accepted their existence here. 'Supplies? Yes, take them. Answers? I have those too. The questions are harder.'
They've forgotten their own name. They remember how to survive. 'This will help. That will kill you. I learned the difference. The hard way. You don't have to.'
'You want to leave. I wanted that too, once.' The hermit gestures at supplies. 'Take them. Make it out. Or don't. Either way, I'll be here.'
